EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1. Introduction
Water has been recognized as a priority area within the PRSP process in Ethiopia. Government of Ethiopia, through the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) has requested WSP-AF assistance in developing the background materials for preparation of the WSS inputs for the full PRSP. This report has been prepared in response to this request, based on discussions with various stakeholders and a synthesis of available studies and consultant reports. It also draws on reports and proceedings of a number of consultations that the MWR has had with different stakeholders at federal and regional levels.
2. Situation Assessment ­ 1: WSS and Poverty Linkage
Nature of Linkage between WSS and Poverty Reduction
Sustainable improvement in water and sanitation conditions is essential to the poor to: i) reduce income losses due to excessive time spent collecting water, ii) increase income earning potential through increase in productivity, iii) reduce the cost of health services especially for water related diseases such as diarrhea, iv) increase income from cattle that depend on water, and v) increase the quality of life of the poor through: positive impacts on maternal and child health, improvements in education enrollment and attendance through better school sanitation, reduced home duties for water collection or caring for siblings, especially for girls, and reduced drudgery and time spent on collection of water, especially for women.
Priorities Expressed by the Poor: The poor also accord priority to these activities in Ethiopia. The priority for health among the poor also indirectly reflects the priority required for water and sanitation activities. A study of the perceptions of the poor in Ethiopia, highlights the importance of water for the poor: lack of clean water sources near their villages was a matter of deep concern among women in rural communities; women carry water on their backs resulting in considerable drudgery; poor urban women stated absence of water and sanitation as a key problem that results in worsening health conditions; lack of water was among the top five priorities in all woredas and in urban sites, and sanitation was also ranked high.
Status of Water Supply and Sanitation in Ethiopia
As per official statistics, coverage of water and sanitation services in Ethiopia is very poor, among the lowest in the world, especially for rural areas, where only 18 percent of population had access to safe water. Conditions in urban areas are on paper better with 80 percent of population having access. However, even in urban areas, most households have access only through common taps, consumption levels are low and unscheduled disruptions in services are common. While Ethiopia fares poorly on most social indicators, its performance on water and sanitation is particularly dismal, particularly in rural areas.
Rural water supply in Ethiopia is provided mostly through point sources. Time and effort spent on fetching water is a major concern among poor women in rural areas. Results from the 1998 welfare monitoring survey suggest that a third of rural population has to walk more than one kilometer to fetch water. Another problem is poor sustainability of sources in rural areas with an estimated 26 to 57 percent of the RWS schemes not functioning. A key issue in urban areas is the poor reliability of supply, both in terms of quantity and breakdowns, also highlighted vividly in consultations with the poor.

Within the wider perspective of poverty reduction, accrual of benefits through improved health, education and income will depend to a great extent on access to wider environmental sanitation and hygiene awareness.
3. Situation Assessment ­ 2: Institutional and Financing Issues
National Water Policy ­ key highlights
Within the framework of the Constitution of the Federal Democratic Republic, the Ministry of Water Resources has adopted a National Water Resources
Management Policy in 1999. One of its main objectives for the WSS sub-sector is to ensure that every Ethiopian citizen has access to water of acceptable quality to satisfy the basic human needs. Key aspects of the policy, which are important for the WSS sub-sector, include:
· Allocation of water resources: envisages high priority to water supply and sanitation for human, livestock and industrial needs for both economic and social benefits;
· Institutional framework for management: visualizes devolving ownership and management autonomy to the lowest possible level with a related emphasis on capacity building, and participation of all stakeholders, including the private sector;
· Financing, water pricing and cost recovery policies: envisages a move to full cost recovery for UWS and partial capital cost sharing and full O&M cost recovery for RWS schemes;
· Technology and maintenance aspects: envisages development of appropriate technologies for local level development and management as well as meeting appropriate standards;
· Integrated water and sanitation policy: emphasizes the need for an integrated approach to water, sanitation and hygiene promotion.
Institutional Arrangements within Decentralization
Within the emerging framework of demand responsive approaches, the role of government is changing from service provision to facilitating and providing an enabling environment. Within the decentralization framework in Ethiopia, different responsibilities are emerging for different levels of government: policy and strategy development, project implementation and monitoring and evaluation. At the federal level, responsibility for the water sector is with the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR). Responsibility for ensuring the provision of these services is with the regions and will be increasingly with woredas.
At the regional level, Regional Water Bureaus (RWBs), along with their other responsibilities for water resources, are also responsible for water and sanitation. In some of the larger regions, woreda water offices with a small staff of two persons have been established. This trend to woreda level will be strengthened in the coming years. Within the context of Ethiopia, NGOs have been an important player in the WSS sector. For RWS schemes Ethiopia Social Rehabilitation and Development Fund (ESRDF) has also played a major role in recent years.
With the government moving away from direct service provision, notion of service providers for WSS services becomes important. In Ethiopia, a number of different forms of service providers exist with

considerable inter and even intra-regional variations, including: Addis Ababa Water and Sewerage Authority (AAWSA), Urban / Town Water Service Unit (TWSU), some Scheme Water Boards (SWB) and at the very local level Water Board (WB) and Village Water and Sanitation Committee (VWSC). There has been limited involvement of the private sector to date, though there is an emerging interest.
Sector Financing and Flow of Funds
Though the National Water Policy envisages financing from domestic financial institutions, so far sector financing has been largely through: budgetary allocations, external debt or grants from bilateral donors and international NGOs sometimes provided either directly to communities or local levels of government, and more recently other off-budget mechanisms such as ESRDF. MWR also proposes to establish a water resource development fund (WRDF). It is envisaged that the WRDF will pool the government and donor resources and channel these in line with the overall sector policy. In the longer term it is visualized that WRDF will also mobilize additional resources.
With decentralization, a large share of federal resources is transferred to regional governments, and regional and woreda governments allocate funds for the WSS sector from their own budgets. However, an effective decentralization process is constrained by: the lack of medium term federal subsidy estimates and donor practices that inhibit multi-year planning. WSS allocations within this emerging decentralization framework depend on the planning process at these levels and the issue of relative preparedness of the WSS sector at this level will be an important determinant.
Based on available information, preliminary and indicative estimates suggest that the current level of funding allocation to the sector is about 34 million US $ per annum. Clearly, to achieve improvements in poverty reduction, water supply and sanitation deserves an equal attention as other sectors such as education, health and roads. However, WSS allocations do not compare favorably with these sectors. This more likely reflects a lack of sector readiness to absorb larger resources rather than a low priority for water supply and sanitation. The priority actions and programs within the sector will have to focus on strengthening overall sector capacity along with specific investment strategies linked to coverage targets.
Key Sector Issues and Potential Measures:
Institutional roles, forms and capacity: Clarity is required in appropriate roles, related forms and capacity of different entities within the decentralization framework. A critical issue is the notion of a service provider, their legal basis with the necessary powers, and their links with the appropriate government units. Key aspects to be addressed are: a) defining institutional models and strengthening capacity of service providers, b) strengthening sector monitoring and regulation, and c) developing and implementing a sector information management system (SIMS) linked to planning and monitoring
Poor sustainability of investments: Measures to enhance sustainability of RWS schemes include: a) emphasis on promotion and participatory and informed demand articulation during the planning stage to improve technology choices, b) improved collection of user fees, c) development of supply chains (in relation to technology choices) that makes access to spare parts easier and cost effective, d) technical support to VWSC and WBs, and e) access to credit for bridge finance for sudden or major repairs and augmentation; and measures for UWS schemes include: a) implementation of tariff setting based on full cost recovery, b) development of guidelines for urban tariff setting including issues related affordability and financial sustainability, c) institutional incentives for urban WSPs to achieve financial viability, d) strengthening

technical and financial capacity of the urban service providers to improve operational efficiency and reduce unaccounted for water (UFW), and e) introduction of consumer services.
Private sector capacity: Capacity of private sector is poor, and a detailed assessment is necessary to identify capacity strengthening measures with an emphasis on local and small scale operators. Possible measures to provide incentives for contracting the private sector as well as building their capacity are necessary.
Neglect of sanitation and hygiene: While integration of sanitation and hygiene with water schemes is mentioned in the Water Policy, institutional responsibilities are currently with the Health sector. Resolution of institutional and financial responsibilities requires a critical emphasis.
Clarifying financing rules to align with WSS policy and priorities: While developing the detailed financing strategy, rules for allocation of and access to public finance will need to be developed to address these sector issues. Some principles that need to be considered are: a) principle of capital subsidies for rural water: with a move to a ceiling on per capita subsidy linked to the notion of basic service levels, b) within urban water the need to reconsider the large capital subsidies to urban water suppliers and move to appropriate subsidy measures to enhance access for the urban poor to improved services and sustainable measures to enhance financial / commercial viability of urban water service providers (UWSUs), c) adequate financial provision for sanitation and hygiene promotion, d) adequate share of management (software) support in project costs, and e) adequate share of sector strengthening and capacity building in total investments.
Linking public finance to results: Within the HIPC and PRSP framework, it is important to shift the traditional emphasis of public finance on inputs to `results' and from `controls' on inputs to achieving the agreed targets for welfare improvement. In WSS sector this is of great importance, as often in the past, issues related to sustainability of capital investments were not addressed leading to poor results even though the input and output targets were reached.
Approach to operationalization of WSS component in WSDP
Following the adoption of National Water Policy, MWR has developed a national water strategy and is currently finalizing the Water Sector Development program (WSDP) through a consultative process. The WSDP preparation process has identified a detailed list of sub-projects through extensive regional consultations. Based on a preliminary review of the SDPs for education, health and roads sectors, operationalizing the WSS component of the WSDP will require further development of:
· an action plan with measures to address institutional and financing issues within the WSS sub-sector,
· model implementation guidelines with details of financing principles, funding and procurement modalities and monitoring arrangements, and appropriately adapted by each region, and
· a detailed annual and periodic review process with adequate stakeholder consultation, a process of donor dialogue as has been developed for other sectors and linked with planning and budgeting cycle and medium term expenditure framework (MTEF).
4. Priorities for Poverty Reduction: Action Plans, Targets and Expenditure Requirements
The water sector development program has identified direct investment requirements for water and sewerage projects in relation to region-wise targets for improved coverage for access to `safe' water for a 15-year time

frame. It has also identified an institutional component for the overall program including both human resource development plans and institutional strengthening programs.
WSS Sub-sector Priorities for Poverty Reduction:
Issue of poor sector capacity and low levels of expenditures for WSS are interlinked and lead to a vicious circle ­ as low levels of investments create low demand for technical and manpower inputs in WSS sector and thus capacity remains underdeveloped. The resulting low sector capacity, means low allocations and expenditures are further curtailed. The action plans for WSS will need to be developed to break this vicious circle through simultaneous development of overall sector capacity and gradual increases in investments for improved services for the poor in rural and urban areas. The three priority areas of focus for PRSP within the WSS sub-sector are:
· Sector Strengthening: to enhance and strengthen overall sector capacity
· Rural Water Supply and Sanitation: to enhance the access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene, and
· Urban Water Supply and Sanitation: to enhance access of the urban poor to improved water supply, sanitation and hygiene promotion
Outcome linked Action Plans for the Institutional Component:
The WSDP has also identified an institutional component for the water sector as a whole with an allocation of about 65 million $ during the first five year phase. While this component is common to all water sub- sectors, a part of this allocation would be for the WSS sub-sector that has a much larger share (46 percent) of envisaged investments. To support the PRSP priorities in the WSS sector within this overall institutional component, outcome linked action plans need to be identified. To meet this need, within each of the three PRSP priority areas for WSS sub-sector, key issues, related action plans over a three-year period and related outcomes to be achieved have been identified. These include:
· Sector Strengthening:
o development of: a financing strategy, and
o development of a sector information and M&E systems
· Rural Water Supply and Sanitation:
o strengthening WBs and VWCs,
o development of a maintenance strategy,
o improved integration of sanitation and hygiene promotion
o development of a strategy for effective supply chains
o investment strategy for new RWS schemes to achieve agreed targets
· Urban Water Supply and Sanitation:
o financially sustainable urban water service providers,
o assessment and implementation of measures to enhance access of the poor to WSS services,

o investment strategy for new/augmentation of UWS schemes to achieve agreed targets
Detailed costing for these actions plans within the institutional component will need to be developed later.
Coverage Targets and Investment Requirements:
As a part of the ongoing preparation of WSDP region-wise targets for enhanced coverage of water in rural and urban areas, and urban sewerage, as well as total resource requirements based on these targets and projects have been identified. The targets for access to `safe' water during the short-term five-year period are: 88 percent in urban and 37 percent in rural areas respectively by 2006. The total requirements during the first phase to achieve the targets are estimated to be 742 million $, or about 150 million $ per annum. Similar long- term investment assessments have also been made under the WSS master plan being prepared under the Environment Support project (ESP). Though this estimation uses a different approach focusing on the technology choices and household affordability considerations, the overall investment requirements are in the same broad range.
Based on preliminary estimates of past allocations to the WSS sector, these requirements are about 5 times the current level of allocations for the sector. PRSP linked priorities discussed above would suggest a greater focus on rural areas and on access for the poor within urban areas. Further priorities may also suggest that greater attention is needed on the needs of pastoral communities. MWR is currently engaged in exploring different priority scenarios within these overall estimates to align more closely with the possible resource envelope for the water sector.
Such scenario assessments would need to include aspects such as: priorities across different sub-sectors (particularly rural areas and a focus on the urban poor), appropriate technology choices and financing / cost recovery rules (as discussed above). It developing these estimates, it would also be necessary to include adequate provision for project development / management costs, including the `software' costs of social mobilization and community support.
Discussion of investment requirements also needs to take into account the offset approach used for federal subsidy allocations to regions, as an increase in regional WSS allocations would be done by reducing other investments, unless there is a significant increase in availability of total resources. At present to overcome this issue, off-budget mechanisms such as ESRDF or the proposed Water Resources Development Fund, are being used. Another preferred option of the Government is to use the `third channel' of direct grant funding by bilateral agencies or NGOs.
5. Monitoring and Evaluation
A clear shift is required within the PRSP framework and WSDP approach from an input based to anoutcome linked expenditure strategy. To make this effective, a shift is required from the project linked M&E systems that have been common in the WSS sector, to a sector-wide M&E. A strong M&E system that is participatory and linked to the overall sector strategy as well as a strong SIMS will enable better program planning along with accountability of those implementing programs.

Current sector capacity for M&E seems to be very weak, though one or two regions have developed input and output monitoring systems in a systematic manner. These existing efforts will need to be assessed to develop proposals for SIMS and related institutional responsibilities. MWR, through its planning department will take the lead in designing and coordinating the development of SIMS and a full M&E system. It would be important to ensure adequate resources allocation for this and develop strong incentives for different actors to collect, analyze and use the information effectively and systematically.
Based on the PRSP linked proposals, indicators have been identified to reflect the outcomes related to achieving better access to improved water and sanitation for the poor in Ethiopia. These will need to be developed consultatively with different stakeholders. Appropriate details related to disaggregation of information and frequency of monitoring will also need to be identified. Additional indicators linked to the inputs and outputs in the sector will also be developed further within the sector M&E strategy.

1. Introduction
Government of Ethiopia completed its Interim PRSP in November 2000. It is currently engaged in the process of preparing the full PRSP based on an Action Plan, detailing the process of consultation and technical preparation. GOE has formed two committees for overseeing and managing the PRSP preparation process: federal steering committee and federal technical committee (FTC). Similar committees have also been formed in each region. In accordance with the Action Plan, GOE has initiated consultations with a number of different stakeholders at federal, regional and district (woreda) levels. These consultations focus on understanding local problems and are to be completed by end December 2001. Further consultations at the federal level are planned with other stakeholders and development partners. Detailed poverty analysis and diagnostic are being undertaken through the Central Statistical Authority and Welfare Monitoring Unit in the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development. The federal technical committee (FTC) will develop a framework for the full PRSP and expects to initiate drafting of the full PRSP from February 2002.
Water has been recognized as a priority area within the PRSP process and Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) will have representation in these committees at both federal and regional levels. It is in this background that the MWR has requested WSP-AF assistance in developing the background materials for preparation of the WSS inputs for the full PRSP. This report has been prepared in response to this request, based on discussions with various stakeholders and a synthesis of available studies and consultant reports. It also draws on reports and proceedings of a number of consultations that the MWR has had with different stakeholders at federal and regional levels.

Sustainability of RWS schemes: Inappropriate choice of technology is also reflected in poor sustainability of sources in rural areas. While monitoring of sustainability is not regular, a 1996 survey by MWR4 suggests that 26 percent of the RWS schemes were not functioning. There was a greater propensity for the hand-pumps and boreholes to have problems as compared to capped springs. Surprisingly, however, the capped springs fared worse in Amhara and Tigary regions. Of the seven regions surveyed, conditions were the worst in Benishangul and Gembela regions. A later survey in Amhara region, however, found the situation worse with 57 percent of the schemes being non-functional5. An inventory of 700 completed RWS schemes supported by the Ethiopian Social Reconstruction and Development Fund (ESRDF) also showed that about 33 percent were not functioning6. It is likely that with the sustainability problems, the actual status of access to safe water is even worse than information reported above.

3. Situation Assessment ­ 2: Institutional and Financing Issues
3.1 National Water Policy ­ key highlights
Within the framework of the Constitution of the Federal Democratic Republic, the Ministry of Water Resources has adopted a National Water Resources Management Policy in 19999. Its overall goal is to enhance and promote "efficient, equitable and optimum utilization of water resources" for sustainable socio- economic development. It recognizes water as an economic good and encompasses water supply and sanitation (WSS), irrigation and hydropower sub sectors. One of its main objectives for the WSS sub-sector is to ensure that every Ethiopian citizen has access to water of acceptable quality to satisfy the basic human needs. The policy provides a guiding framework within which more detailed sub-sector strategies and institutional reforms will need to be developed. Key aspects of the policy, which are important for the WSS sub-sector, are:
· Allocation of water resources: gives high priority to water supply and sanitation for human, livestock and industrial needs. It recognizes that the allocation needs to be based on both economic and social benefits;
· Institutional framework for management: visualizes devolving ownership and management autonomy to the lowest possible level within the emerging decentralization framework, effective coordination mechanisms for collaboration among different stakeholders, and related emphasis on capacity building;
· Financing, water pricing and cost recovery policies: envisages a move towards full cost recovery for urban water supply and partial capital cost sharing and full O&M cost recovery for rural water supply schemes as well as promotion of domestic commercial and micro-finance institutions in financing water investments;
· Technology and maintenance aspects: envisages development of appropriate technologies for local level development and management as well as meeting appropriate standards;
· Integrated water and sanitation policy: puts an emphasis on the need for an integrated approach to water and sanitation, and a clear identification of responsibilities of government and other stakeholders for sanitation and hygiene promotion.
MWR has prepared a national water strategy to articulate implementation of the Water Policy. Some regions plan to adapt the strategies to address the regional context. Detailed implementation guidelines are also planned to be developed first at the federal and later in each region.
3.2 Institutional Arrangements within Decentralization Framework
Within the emerging framework of demand responsive approaches, the role of government is gradually changing from service provision to being a facilitator and providing an enabling environment. Actual service provision is with different service providers in rural and urban areas.
Role of Government, NGOs and the Private Sector: Within the decentralization framework in Ethiopia, different responsibilities are emerging for different levels of government, ranging from policy and strategy

Federal Government (MWR): At the federal level, responsibility for policy and strategy development for the water sector is with the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR). It also coordinates with external agencies for financing the sector investments. MWR is responsible for developing the Sector Development Program for WSS sector for Ethiopia. With the enhanced role of regional government, role of MWR is also to ensure effective monitoring and evaluation and provide capacity building support. With the envisaged policy emphasis on appropriate pricing in urban areas the federal government will also need to explore the possibility of an independent framework for economic regulation in the sector10.
Regional and Woreda Governments: Under the emerging decentralization framework, responsibility for ensuring the provision of these services will be increasingly with the regions and woredas (districts). The Regional Water Bureaus11, along with their other responsibilities for water resources, are responsible for water and sanitation at the regional level. At the zonal level there are Water Departments, which were established in 1996 to support development, implementation and regulation of WSS activities. Zonal level essentially represents a deconcentration of administration. Gradually, with recent developments, the emphasis is shifting from the zone to transferring responsibilities to the woreda level. In some of the larger regions, Amhara, Tigray, Oromiya and SNNPR, woreda water offices, with a small staff of two persons have been established. Cooperation with woreda education and health offices, especially for sanitation, hygiene promotion and small water schemes, needs to be explored.12
Ethiopia Social Rehabilitation and Development Fund (ESRDF): Government of Ethiopia established ESRDF in 1996 to fund demand driven small community sub-projects on a grant basis. Its proposed portfolio included rural water supply and sanitation with a focus on simple technologies that would be cost-effective and be easy for community management. ESRDF has attempted to follow the principles of demand responsive approach by ensuring community participation in demand expression, community share of at least 10 percent in capital costs and complete community responsibility for O&M. Over the past 5 years, it has funded nearly 2000 small schemes serving an estimated 2 million population. Its approach has demonstrated the possibility of using the DRA in practice, and is likely to have influenced the development of national water policy. Over the years, in some regions, there has been a trend to have a larger proportion of larger and more complex schemes. In future operation, further attention may, however, be required for: strengthening support to communities during planning of sub-projects, better integration of the sanitation and hygiene components, ensure supply chains for more effective maintenance and closer links with the sector institutions at the region, zone and woreda levels.

3.3 Sector Financing and Flow of Funds
Funding for water supply in Ethiopia seems to be largely through federal and regional budgets and some off budget mechanisms such as the ESRDF or bilateral agencies and NGOs. There is a critical need to identify an appropriate financing strategy for the sector to address the key issues discussed below.
Funding and Transfer Mechanisms: Though the National Water Policy envisages financing from domestic financial institutions, so far WSS sector financing in the past has been largely through: budgetary allocations, external debt or grants from bilateral donors and international NGOs sometimes provided directly either to communities or local levels of government, and more recently, other off-budget mechanisms such as the ESRDF. MWR also proposes to establish a water resource development fund (WRDF). It is envisaged that the WRDF will pool the government and donor resources and channel these in line with the overall sector policy. In the longer term it is visualized that WRDF will also mobilize additional resources.
Fiscal Decentralization: With decentralization, a large share of federal resources is transferred to regional governments. For example, during the current financial year, about 30 percent of total federal resources are

The regional subsidy is divided among the regions according to a formula approved by the Council of Federation using criteria related to: population, level of development and level of revenue effort16. An established tradition of bottom-up identification of priorities and flexibility in implementation allows shifting resources across projects. However, an effective decentralization process is constrained by: the lack of medium term federal subsidy estimates and donor practices that inhibit multi-year planning17.
In principle, the regional governments also allocate funds for the WSS sector from their own budgets, and the woreda governments are likely to do so in the future. Some regions have initiated block transfers to zone levels and on a pilot basis to woreda level. Further developments in decentralization will depend on both on greater predictability of transfers and external funds, as well as improved local capacity for planning and implementation. WSS allocations within this emerging decentralization framework depend on the planning process at these levels and the issue of preparedness of the WSS sector will be important also at this level. Unfortunately, a detailed analysis of WSS financing at the regional level is constrained, as most readily available information for regional level allocations and expenditures do not give a disaggregated analysis for WSS18. In more recent development, the Government intends to further deepen the fiscal decentralization process to the woreda level with transfer of woreda block grants.
Flow of External Funds: External funds are an important source for Ethiopia's development expenditure. World Bank (2000b) identifies three channels used for aid disbursements: i) funds disbursed through the federal ministry of finance (either earmarked or unearmarked assistance), ii) aid negotiated and disbursed directly through sector bodies, and iii) funds disbursed directly (outside the budget process) by donors or NGOs for development purposes. Government has a clear preference for resources through the first channel (and preferably unearmarked) that would help to maintain integrity of and strengthen the overall planning, budgeting and accounting systems.
For the current financial year (2001-02), external loans and grants are expected to account for 31 percent of the total budget, 61 percent of the federal capital budgets and about 28 percent of the federal subsidy to regions19. Donor funds included in the regional budgets are essentially offset against the treasury subventions20. For the Ministry of Water Resources, external aid constituted over 80 percent of its capital expenditure allocations, and over 95 percent for the WSS sub-sector. A number of efforts have been made by Government of Ethiopia to improve coordination and management of external aid, including the move to sector development programs for at least three sectors. Institutional roles, forms and capacity: Despite the attempt made to clarify the institutional roles in the paragraphs above, considerable more clarity is required in appropriate roles, related forms and capacity of different entities. A critical issue is the notion of a service provider, their legal basis with the necessary powers, and their links with the appropriate government units within the decentralization framework. Some of the important sector roles related to regulation, M&E and information management require further attention as these are being neglected at present.
· Defining institutional models and strengthening capacity of service providers: Different institutional forms of service providers exist in regions. Appropriate institutional models need to be developed with

Efforts have been now initiated in most regions. Along with this clarity, support is required to strengthen their capacities for planning, consumer services, operations and financial management.
· Poor monitoring and regulation: With the emergence of a large umber of service providers, it becomes essential to monitor their operational performance. Such monitoring may be done within the decentralization framework through the existing RWBs, zonal departments and the planned woreda offices. While this is envisaged as per existing arrangements, in most regions monitoring does not receive adequate emphasis. For urban WSS service providers, an independent regulatory framework becomes essential to ensure that the tariffs are set to reflect consumer preference as well as viability of the provider. Maximizing the operational performance becomes important in this context. Development of such a regulatory framework will also enable gradual entry of the private sector in urban water supply provision.
· Lack of sector information management systems (SIMS): Better sector planning needs to be based on well managed and regularly updated sector information systems. MWR, as it moves away from direct participation in water projects, and shifts its role to planning and strategy development, needs to be at forefront of managing this. Such a system should include: periodic assessment of the sector resources and operational performance.
Poor sustainability of Investments: Decapitalization of investments in the sector is common both in rural and urban areas. For rural areas, studies done during the last five years indicated that a large proportion (ranging from a third to a half) of water schemes are not functional24. For urban areas, the problems are related to poor financial viability, and technical and managerial capacities.
· Rural water: In rural areas, poor maintenance appears to be a common problem. A number of issues that need to be addressed in this regard: i) Inadequate emphasis on promotion and participatory and informed demand articulation during the planning stage results in poor technology choices and a lack of community `ownership' of the scheme, ii) poor user fees collection, both due to inadequate management and up-front clarity of rules results in lack of resources to undertake timely maintenance of assets, iii) lack of or poorly developed supply chains (in relation to technology choices) that makes access to spare parts difficult and unduly costly, iv) inadequate technical support available to VWSC and WBs, and v) lack of access to credit for bridge finance for sudden or major repairs and augmentation.
· Urban Water: In urban areas sustainability of investments is also threatened, as timely and regular maintenance is not undertaken. The problems that underlie this trend have been: i) inappropriate tariff setting without an emphasis on full cost recovery, ii) lack of clear guidelines for urban tariff setting including issues related to affordability and financial sustainability, iii) inappropriate or lack of institutional incentives for urban WSPs to achieve financial viability and improved operational performance, iv) poor technical and financial capacity among the urban service providers that leads to high levels unaccounted for water (UFW), and v) poor or non-existent

Linking public finance to results: Within the HIPC and PRSP framework, it is important to shift the traditional emphasis of public finance on inputs to `results' and from `controls' on inputs to achieving the agreed targets for welfare improvement. Such an emphasis makes it possible to track welfare improvements as outcomes of specific expenditure priorities. Such an approach also makes it possible to explore alternative means of achieving the results and in changing and adapting the inputs to ensure sustainability. In WSS sector this is of great importance, as often in the past, issues related to sustainability of capital investments were not addressed leading to poor results even though the input and output targets were reached. Such an approach would also require a clear identification of results / outcome indicators that need to be monitored as discussed further in Section 3.3.
3.5 Operationalizing the WSS Component of the Sector Development Program (SDP)
MWR has recently developed a water sector development program (WSDP). It covers all the key sub-sectors including: water resources, irrigation, hydropower and water and sanitation. MWR through its consultants have carried out detailed consultation at the regional level to identify the local priorities, articulation of targets and linked sub-projects. Water and sanitation is an important component within the WSDP. Operationalization of this component within the SDP provides an opportunity to address some of the key institutional and financing issues discussed above.
Background of Other SDPs in Ethiopia: Ethiopia has taken lead in developing sector development programs (SDPs) for some of its important sectors to facilitate strategic planning for the sectors and a framework for coordination of donor funding. SDPS have been developed and operational for three sectors: education, health and road construction. The SDPs were generally preceded by a number of studies related to institutional and financing issues in each sector. These have been operational for a few years now and provide valuable lessons in future preparation of other sector SDPs. Some of these lessons are: i) preparation of SDPs need to be done in consultation with regional governments so that their priorities are also adequately reflected, ii) the initial period presented considerable problems in donor consultation and commitment, iii)

donor discomfort with the initial lack of a common and consultatively agreed implementation manual, iv) many of the standards and modalities in the implementation guidelines were developed at the federal level, and considerable efforts were required to incorporate the required regional variations, v) considerable additional demand on financial information flows, and the need to simplify and stream line procurement procedures, and vi) need for a well articulated transition phase for introducing some of the critical institutional reforms. This proved to be critical as considerable capacity building support was required at regional and woreda levels within the decentralization framework. Further development in these SDPs visualizes a streamlining with the federal government's five-year plan process. Close links of SDPs are also envisaged with the other governance and financial management related reforms such as civil service reforms and medium term planning framework.
Approach to operationalization of WSS component in WSDP: The WSDP preparation process has identified a detailed list of sub-project ideas through extensive regional consultations. Based on a preliminary review of the SDPs for education, health and roads sectors, operationalizing the WSS component of the WSDP will require further development of:
· an action plan with measures to address institutional and financing issues within the WSS sub-sector,
· model implementation guidelines with details of financing principles, funding and procurement modalities and monitoring arrangements, to be developed at the federal level and appropriately adapted by each region, and
· a detailed annual and periodic review process with adequate stakeholder consultation, and particularly a process of donor dialogue as has been developed for other sectors. This review process should preferably be also linked with other important stages in the planning and budgeting cycle such as presentation of the federal and regional budgets and medium term expenditure framework (MTEF).
Implementation of the WSDP can usefully be done through a demand responsive, decentralized approach. Appropriate financing mechanism need to be identified for this.
4. Priorities for Poverty Reduction: Action Plans, Targets and Expenditure Requirements
The water sector development program has identified direct investment requirements for water and sewerage projects in relation to region-wise targets for improved coverage for access to `safe' water for a 15-year time frame. It has also identified an institutional component for the overall program including both human resource development plans and institutional strengthening programs.
4.1 WSS Sub-sector Priorities for Poverty Reduction:
Issue of poor sector capacity and low levels of expenditures for WSS are interlinked and lead to a vicious circle ­ as low levels of investments create low demand for technical and manpower inputs in WSS sector and thus capacity remains underdeveloped. The resulting low sector capacity, means low allocations and expenditures are further curtailed. The action plans for WSS will need to be developed to break this vicious circle through simultaneous development of overall sector capacity and gradual increases in investments for improved services in rural and urban areas. The three priority areas of focus for PRSP within the WSS sub- sector are:

· Sector Strengthening: to enhance and strengthen overall sector capacity to improve WSS service in a decentralized environment
· Rural Water Supply and Sanitation: to enhance access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene, and
· Urban Water Supply and Sanitation: to enhance access of the urban poor to improved water supply, sanitation and hygiene promotion
4.2 Outcome linked Action Plans for the Institutional Component:
The WSDP has identified an institutional component for the water sector as a whole with an allocation of about 65 million $ during the first five year phase. While this component is common to all water sub-sectors, a part of this allocation would be for the WSS sub-sector that has a much larger share (46 percent) of envisaged investments. To support the PRSP priorities in the WSS sector within this overall institutional component, outcome linked action plans need to be identified. To meet this need, within each of the three PRSP priority areas for WSS sub-sector, key issues, related action plans over a three-year period and related outcomes to be achieved have been identified (refer to Table 7). These include:
· Sector Strengthening
o development of a financing strategy,
o development of a sector planning and information management system and linked sector M&E system, with related capacity building for MWR, regions and local governments
· Rural Water Supply and Sanitation:
o strengthening VWSCs,
o development of a supply chains and maintenance (SCM) strategy,
o improved integration of sanitation and hygiene promotion and, and
o investment strategy for new RWS schemes to achieve agreed targets
· Urban Water Supply and Sanitation:
o financially sustainable urban water service providers,
o strengthening capacity of water boards,
o assessment and implementation of measures to enhance access of the poor to WSS services,
o framework for economic regulation for urban water supply starting with comparative performance assessment of UWS service providers, and
o investment strategy for new/augmentation of UWS schemes to achieve agreed targets
Detailed costing for these actions plans within the institutional component will need to be developed later.

5. Monitoring and Evaluation
5.1 Issues in Development of a Sector M&E
A clear shift is required within the PRSP framework and sector development program approach from an input based to an outcome linked expenditure strategy. To make this effective, a shift is required from the project linked M&E systems that are common in the WSS sector, to a sector-wide M&E. A strong M&E
29From global experience these may be at least 10 to 15 percent of project investments. These costs will also need to be accounted for in projections of investment requirements. 30See the discussion above in footnote 21.
20  WSS Inputs For Ethiopia Full PRSP
system that is participatory and linked to the overall sector strategy will enable better program planning along with accountability of those implementing programs.
A review of PRSPs in Africa suggests that often PRSP linked proposals for M&E system seem to focus mainly on monitoring poverty impacts, especially through special household surveys and participatory poverty assessments (PPAs). However, there is inadequate attention on implementation monitoring, especially related to inputs, outputs and outcomes. To really measure strategy effectiveness an emphasis is needed equally on the latter. For an effective sector M&E system, institutional responsibility (across MWR, RWB, ZD, WWO and WSPs) and flow of information needs to be clearly articulated. While some innovations exist at different levels in Ethiopia, a systematic and linked M&E system does not exist at present. At each level appropriate participatory mechanisms need to be developed and institutionalized over time to ensure wider accountability. Finally, as observed earlier, it is necessary to improve the impact monitoring for WSS through country level household surveys and poverty analysis already being carried out.
To address these issues, development of the institutional framework for M&E needs to be developed within three guiding principles:
· Information collection and analysis at every level of government with a three-way flow of information for dissemination­ upwards and downwards, and to other stakeholders;
· Selection of institutions at each level with an adequate institutional capacity and budget allocation to ensure reliable and timely collection and analysis of information
· Need to link with other multi-purpose and inter-linked M&E tools, such as welfare monitoring surveys and public expenditure reviews, to enable adoption of more cost-efficient tools and also to provide a comparative picture across different sectors.
5.2 Institutional Arrangements for Sector M&E in WSS
Within an overall M&E system, three components may be identified:
· Sector Performance: a WSS internal sector level M&E that is integrated with the WSS institutional arrangements and hierarchy (MWR, RWB, Zonal Department, TWSU and woreda water offices). In the future as an independent regulatory framework is developed and made operational, it will also take on independent performance monitoring responsibilities for urban water supply services;
· Sector Outcomes: links with wider and multi-sectoral M&E systems such as: welfare monitoring surveys, PPAs (if taken up), public expenditure reviews (PER), census and joint donor reviews. This will help ensure that information for WSS related concerns and outcome/impacts are better coordinated and the quality of information is ensured. Responsibility for this should vest with MWR, planning department;
· Sector Networking and Influence: Use of M&E to influence decisions related to the sector is essential. This requires efforts on two fronts: i) to link effectively with the overall sector planning process, both internally to the sector and as linked to wider macro planning. This necessitates that information and reports from the sector M&E system are made available to key stakeholders at different levels in the planning process and to match with the planning and budget cycles, and ii) links are necessary to be developed with key stakeholders through appropriate forums, such as networks and associations, including promotion of such bodies, as appropriate.

doc.abstracts: Water has been recognized as a priority area within the PRSP process in Ethiopia. Government of Ethiopia, through the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) has requested WSP-AF assistance in developing the background materials for preparation of the WSS inputs for the full PRSP. This report has been prepared in response to this request, based on discussions with various stakeholders and a synthesis of available studies and consultant reports. It also draws on reports and proceedings of a number of consultations that the MWR has had with different stakeholders at federal and regional levels. This paper includes the following headings: introduction; situation assessment 1 - WSS and poverty linkage; situation assessment 2 - policy, institutional and financing issues; priorities for poverty reduction - action plans, targets, and expenditure requirements; and WSS sector monitoring and evaluation.
